title: Street Coder: The rules to break and how to break them
author: Sedat Kapanoglu

title: Rust in Action
author: Tim McNamara
review: Rust in Action its a great introduction into System's Programming. This book not only made me improve my way of thinking around Rust, but also to play around with whats available in a Computer System.  Tim McNamara does a great job explaining the fundamentals on System's Programming and also applies Rust on top of it. If you didn't know he is also doing Rust courses on LinkedIn Learning!

title: The Rust Programming Language
author: Steve Klabnik & Carol Nichols
review: I started to learn Rust back in 2018 writing simple programs. I was looking into understanding better the key concepts of the language and how to "Think in Rust". It doesnt matter which language you come from, at the beginning with Rust you will feel like you are fighting the compiler, if you come from dynamic programming languages like JavaScript or Python, lower level concepts like memory management and pointers might sound "alien" to you. Well this book not only goes through these concepts, but also walks you through Systems Programming using a practical approach. You can also read the book for free online on it's mdBook version.

title: The Go Programming Language
author: Alan Donovan & Brian Kernighan
review: Golang was a thing back in 2018, dont't get me wrong, it is still very popular. But by 2018/19 it was a thing on the internet, everyone was getting a taste of Golang, either in DevOps land or WebDev for Servers. Well I got interest into it too, and as it was really different to my background languages I decided to grab a book and get into it. I learned Golang and used it  for a little while, it called my attention the First-Class Citizen Support for imaginary numbers!

title: Fullstack React: The Complete Guide to ReactJS and Friends
author: Anthony Accomazzo, Nathaniel Murray & Ari Lerner
review: Book I used to learn by doing ReactJS, back in the day I used to go through tutorials and ReactJS Documentation. It was thanks to this book that I found Semantic UI. I wasn't keen to use Relay/GraphQL back in the day but its also covered!

title: Java: How to Program, 9th Edition (Deitel)
author: Paul Deitel & Harvey Deitel
review: While doing my course on Java SE 7 in ITMaster I was using this book as reference, it brings a great introduction to Java Programming.

title: Java: How to Program, 9th Edition (Deitel)
author: Paul Deitel & Harvey Deitel
review: While doing my course on Java SE 7 in ITMaster I was using this book as reference, it brings a great introduction to Java Programming.

title: JavaScript & jQuery: Interactive Front-End Web Development
author: Jon Duckett
review: This was part of the same experience as when reading "HTML and CSS: Design and Build Websites"

title: HTML and CSS: Design and Build Websites
author: Jon Duckett
review: After doing HTML & CSS for while I also learned JavaScript on the way. I got more and more into JavaScript but while looking for learning matereals I stepped upon Jon Duckett's Web Development Book Series and I felt in love with their approach on beatiful visual design and clear explanations. These books explains the anatomy on HTML, CSS, JavaScript and JQuery syntax using beautiful visual examples which make really easy to understand the purpose of each token. After founding these books I always recommend them for new developers who want to explore the Web Development world.

title: Head First HTML and CSS
author: Elisabeth Robson, Eric Freeman
review: While reading Head First Python, I was also getting into Web Development by going through w3Schools tutorials. Head First Python helped me a lot understanding the "why" on certain statements, while w3Schools was good I wanted to go a step beyond in a more practical approach and started to read Head First HTML & CSS, I learned fundamentals on HTML & CSS from this book that helped my starting to write my own websites.

title: Head First Python
author: Paul Barry
review: This was my very first introduction to programming, and I couldn't have asked for a better book to start with. Python is a simple language, it makes it easy to jump into the field and Head First Python also brings a great introduction not only to Python but also to programming in general. The book is full of exercises and examples that make it easy to understand the concepts and the language. I highly recommend this book to anyone who is looking to start programming.
